replies.body: Upvoted because I actually support this idea in some way shape or form, even if not in the way that was talked about in that post.

I only vaguely recall the original post, but I also would support having something like this implemented.  I can understand the reservations Riot has, with regards to how players might misuse the personal toxicity meter, but I haven't heard any real reason why players shouldn't know how many of their reports are considered valid.

What do you mean by personal toxicity meter?  If anything it's a good way for a player to see that perhaps there attitudes leave something to be desired OR that you affirmation that you are a team mate with a decent attitude.

I doubt I will be able to put it in the exact words that the original posters have used in the many threads that it has been discussed, but it's been discusses that some of the more toxic players would use something like this as a way of towing the line.  They would be toxic up to a point, and when the report card shows that they are close to punishment, they would back off on toxicity for the sole purpose of avoiding punishment.  And when the report card comes back clean they would resume toxicity, because they know they are no longer in danger of punishment.

The problem is, it literally takes 3 months to drop 1 punishment tier, so if someone is on the "verge" of punishment, they'll be there for 3 months. it's not like they can behave for 2 days and then "let loose."

And, back in the real world: People aren't generally deliberately toxic. They are toxic as a reaction to other toxic behavior far more often. When you're the only person on your team 5/0 while everyone else fed both 0/6 and their turrets, you're darn tootin' the 5/0 is going to react to 4 people going 0/6, Especially if they watch those fights from across the map, and just see a Vayne go up , walk into the opponent, and stand in 1 spot auto attacking. Or watch a Orianna push Zoe to turret 6 times in a row, only to have that Orianna ganked by Udyr 6 times in a row, giving the Zoe 6 free kills Your 5/0 Jungler's also going to get pretty mad when a team is pinged 1:30 in advance of an infernal drake spawn, and literally no one goes, no one even wards, or they commit suicide to a brawl 15 seconds before the spawn. Or what about the Support Nami who's timing every objective, is carrying 3/0/10, pings everything out, verbally telling team in type, and calling skills gets literally ignored on every single call in a 40 minute game, and you lose because your team just doesn't care about objectives?


These rages aren't the result of intentionally wanting to be toxic. They are the result of legitimate responses to teams throwing a game every way they possibly can, not caring that they are, or actual inting (How do 3 lanes feed 24 kills by level 7 when Evelynn went 5/0 ganking them before 6? I've had it happen!). They aren't planned or something someone can just look at a report card and say "I need to  tone it down and prevent from occuring." They may try. But the vast majority fail.
This is a glorious idea. This would allow us to track both how toxic we are as well as how effective our reports are.
Finally a reminder about something decent that doesn't promise to be repeated every so often.  Have my upvote.

You actually think we will ever get them? Riot doesn't want this system to be transparent. It allows them to be completely shady with how they actually dole out punishments (ie completely automated with exactly 0 human input). Showing people these would allow people to have actual hard evidence to dispute a punishment, which is something that Riot would utterly destroy Riot's narrative of "only 5% (or whatever they say) of the player base ever gets punished".
There's nothing shady about it. Don't tell your teammates to kill themselves or use slurs, and you're already on top of 99% of the people who complain about their bans here.

I've gotten a 14 day ban with a 30 game chat ban and 15 game ranked restriction for saying "gg afk" (note: did not actually afk, and also proceeded to stop talking after this, making this the only "bad" thing I said). When I finally got a support rep to explain this, they accused me of intense negativity and player harassment. Not shady you say? I beg to differ.

Probably because someone just got off a 14 day ban and is on extremely thin ice. The next punishment for anything after a 14 is always a perm.

The part where I am, by definition, THE VICTIM of toxic behavior (aka trolling). By Riot's own fucking definition of trolling, I was victimized by the troll and fell victim to his/her technique of eliciting toxic behavior. To ban me for being the victim is pretty _<Removed by Moderation>_

Considering the fact that a single, actual AFK will not trigger a 14-day ban on an account in good standing and the fact that you've confirmed a credible source verified you as being toxic in game, no. There's nothing shady about the fact you were punished for more than what you're leading on to believe happened.

I mean, how isn't it transparent? Do you feel that way because they don't provide a full list of words that you shouldn't say? Because you have no idea if your report mattered? Because you felt you were wrongly reported? We have even been explained and shown how the code for reports work. The whole "[  :  >0 ] " thing.

Also, what do you mean no human input? The bot doesn't just auto punish you. Someone had to report you, which means human input. Outside of that they do tinker with the bot and do manual reviews.

I think the narrative is something like "only 5% punished are punished again" which is done each tier of the punishment system. And the "0.006 get perma." Both of which can still be relevant from the simple number of accounts. Some perm players make a new account, you have idle accounts, and accounts that are used for smurfing.

Finally, how exactly does this information help dispute a punishment?

For starters, they don't even provide a manner by which to see whether or not your account is flagged. This is a big deal, because (this is from personal experience) a flagged account can get a 14 day ban for literally a single offense. Whereas a non-flagged account (aka my friend who goes fkin nuts sometimes) can pretty much get away with anything short of actual (and consistent) use of racial slurs and "kys" type stuff.

Here is the thing though. You don't go straight to a 14 day from nothing unless you used slurs or kys. I can concur that the old warnings they gave were nice. Now your first chat restriction is your flag that you need to change. 
Your friend must just be lucky enough to not get reported. The system won't take action unless they are reported and it is done in team or all chat. If he whispers it to you in game, then perhaps avoids it.

Actually this is categorically incorrect according to Riot themselves. You get "strikes". Strike 1 is 5 game chat restrict. Strike 2 is 15 game chat restrict. Strike 3 is 14 day time ban. Anything after that is an automatic permaban. The severity of the offense is of no consequence (again, Riot actually stated this, and based on my current experience, they are sticking to that mentality).

I've read that as well, but they also added that extremely hateful terms such as "KYS" can result in an instant ban even with no prior offenses. 

Hence the people fishing for others to use these phrases and getting them banned for it.

TBH, I think Riot is lying about that bit. There is no human interaction with reports anymore. My proof is that I was banned no more than 2 minutes after leaving a game AT 3AM ON A SUNDAY MORNING (Riot is most certainly NOT paying people to read reports at this hour...).

>Hence the people fishing for others to use these phrases and getting them banned for it.

The majority of my bans over the past 1-2 years (previous, I was actually a dick and deserved them) were for "harassing" someone that was being overtly passive-aggressive (not possible to detect by a bot) or just outright trolling (ie feeding by proxy). Somehow, the report of a person that spend the entire game "split pushing" with a kda of 0/10 has an equal say in who/what is toxic...just fucking great.

>There is no human interaction with reports anymore. 

Not with stuff that triggers the IFS "really bad" filter, anyways. Try it yourself - make a new account, play a matchmade game, say kys twice, have a friend report you. You'll get the 14 day ban a few minutes after the game is over. Start a new game before you get the ban notice, do it again, finish the game out. You'll get the 14 day message. Log back in again, the second report will have processed, and the account will be permabanned.

>Somehow, the report of a person that spend the entire game "split pushing" with a kda of 0/10 has an equal say in who/what is toxic...just fucking great.

So you think you should be able to tell trolls to kill themselves? I'm not sure what you're getting at here.

Part of your profile should have a "Reputation" section.  That section could show how many times you AFK'ed this season, been penalized etc, but more importantly how many times you've also been honored and been positive.  Make that honor mean something.
